replies.body: Dont get me wrong, Rekkles is *really* good, But i question if he is better than Deft or Imp.

The thing is. Rekkles isn't better than Imp or Deft. But this article isn't only about that. It is about the importance of the player to the team too. Fnatic wouldn't even go to worlds if they didn't have Rekkles. While on the other hand Imp and Deft have more importand players in their team (Dade , Spirit , Dandy , Mata).

The Fnatic that went to worlds last year was literally the exact same team sans Rekkles, and they made semis. And it's not like Rekkles is some prodigious shotcaller that's offering intangible benefits in game, either - he's just a very powerful weapon for the team to use, like a lot of ADCs.

You could put any good western player on Dark Passage, and they'd be so fucking important to their team you wouldn't believe. That wouldn't make them better players, though, and is possibly the most ridiculously arbitrary qualifier for power rankings ever. Like, "Oh yeah, that guy's pretty good, probably #15 or so. But if his teammates were shit, he'd be way higher."

Also, Dade is the only person on Blue who's potentially more important than Deft. If you're into EU, I like to think of it as similar to the relationship between Froggen and Tabzz.

At least all EUADCs played so good at worlds... Puszu,Ganja, Yellowstar,Yellowpete, and Tabbz all played good in the last 2 worlds....

There *is* a difference between Puszu's performance at s3 worlds and Rekkles' performance at least in this split imo.
Puszu was doing great at a time that both sOAZ and xPeke were performing really well. Rekkles has been performing close to all the time this season, while xPeke and sOAZ were rather lackluster, to put it mildly (this point might be debatable, but I'd love to defend myself on that topic).
He hasn't been solocarrying his team, mostly because YellOwStaR was doing great as well, so they were carrying their team from bot together.

But compared to s3's fnatic, this year's fnatic has a much greater focus on snowballing the game from bot than it did last year, when Cyanide was mostly camping mid/top to get xPeke going and keep sOAZ in the game.

This list has been heavily criticized, and for good reason. It appears like Riot's trying to highlight NA & EU LCS players as having an equal footing with China and Korea when it's not even remotely close

Just to clarify where I'm coming from - I'm an NA native, and I watch both NA and EU LCS religiously. As you could maybe guess from my summoner icon, I'd love nothing more than if Alliance won worlds. I have no particular emotional investment in any Korean teams (that are attending this tournament, anyways).

However, I'm unconvinced that western players and teams are currently able to rival them, and I get the impression that these power rankings are primarily motivated by a desire to push a specific narrative (that the West is secretly just as good as Korea, and it's only nebulous concepts like 'teamwork' that separate the regions), rather than by a desire to accurately represent the scene. 

If somebody who's only just getting into League of Legends esports reads these articles and actually believes that Rekkles, as an individual player, is superior to the best that Korea has to offer - I see that as an issue. Which is why I'm taking time out of my day to post my thoughts on the matter.

If you disagree, that's fine - but I'd rather hear your opinion of Rekkles as a player and *why* he's superior to Imp and Deft. Your post, although pretty amusing, only really tells me that you disagree - it doesn't give me any new ideas to work with or anything that could maybe change my mind.
